Nonlinear relationship with temperature described; inverted-U shape above 15°C, negative response to low temperatures (<12°C); quantitative value not provided but setting value to 0 to indicate no effect was specified.

This quantitative result represents the reduction in annual industrial output when replacing days with an average temperature of [21-24°C) with days at 30°C. The data range ends in 2007 so that may be a useful year to associate with these findings.

This quantitative result represents the reduction in annual industrial output when replacing days with an average temperature of [21-24°C) with days at 12°C or below. The data range ends in 2007 so that may be a useful year to associate with these findings. The analysis includes lagged temperature effects.

Cumulative effect of a 1°C increase in winter temperature on stationary output. Assuming 2007 as the end of the study period.
Cumulative effect of a 1°C increase in winter temperature on office machinery output. Assuming 2007 as the end of the study period.
The result indicates that a 1°C increase in summer temperature leads to a 7.51% increase in value added per worker in high-temperature regions defined by above-median humidity.
The result indicates that a 1°C increase in summer temperature leads to a 5.27% increase in value added per worker in high-temperature regions with above-median rainfall.
